This pos sibility had been telegraphed last week when an American spokesman in Paris said the Communist side was dike “the high‐pressure salesman who tries to obtain immediate signature of an incomplete contract.”
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Last Australian Soldiers In Vietnam Fly Home
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 18 (Reuters)— A fully laden C‐130 Hercules transport took off from Tan Son. Nhut air base today, carrying home about 60 Aus tralian soldiers and ending Australia's role In the Viet nam war.

headline: What Next on Peace? Some Key Questions
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 — Henry A. Kissinger, in his news conference yesterday, gave the Administration's rationale for the failure so far to achieve a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war. Mr. Kissinger's presentation answered some of the questions that have arisen recently, left others unanswered, or in dispute and raised some new ones. What follows is an effort to clarify what is known, what is not known, and what can only be surmised.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Doves in Senate Hold Off Criticism of Snag at Paris
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17—The negative turn in the Paris peace negotiations provoked a com mon reaction of disappointment among Senators today, but it was still unclear whether the disappointment would lead to renewed criticism of the Administration's Vietnam policies.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Tho Leaves Peking
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Monday, Dec. 18 (Reuters)—Le Duc Tho, North Vietnam's chief negotiator at the Paris peace talks, left here for Hanoi today after receiving assurances from Premier Chou En‐lai of China's firm support in the Vietnam conflict.

headline: Questions on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Henry A. Kissinger's an nouncement that the Vietnam peace talks had failed to reach “a just and fair agree ment” has raised many unanswered questions. An article attempting to answer some appears on Page 3.

headline: Saigon Sees Hanoi Perfidy
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 18 (Reuters)— The South Vietnamese Govern ment said today that the failure of the secret Paris talks was evidence of Communist perfidy.

headline: Saigon Reports Heavy Fighting, Killing 151 Near Quang Tri City
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 18 (AP) — The Saigon command reported yes terday that South Vietnamese paratroopers, backed by air strikes and artillery, killed 151 enemy soldiers in two days of fighting as they extended their control around Fire Base Anne eight miles southwest of Quang Tri city.

headline: Doves in Senate Hold Off Criticism of Snag at Paris
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17—The negative turn in the Paris peace negotiations provoked a com mon reaction of disappointment among Senators today, but it was still unclear whether the disappointment would lead to renewed criticism of the Ad ministration's Vietnam policies.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Haig Flying to Saigon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 — The White House announced today that Henry A. Kissinger's deputy, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., was flying to South east Asia to brief the leaders of South Vietnam, Laos, Cam bodia and Thailand on the current impasse at the Paris negotiations.

headline: The War's Urban Toll: Cities Are Now Slums
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 17—The war damage in South Vietnam that is most noticeable and will take long est to repair is not the millions of bomb craters and defoliated acres of jungle, but the effect on cities—most especially this city, the capital.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: KISSINGER'S AIDE SERB INDOCHINA TO BRIEF LEADERS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17— The White House announced today that Henry A. Kissinger's deputy, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., was flying to South east Asia to brief the leaders of South Vietnam, Laos, Cam bodia and Thailand on the current impasse at the Paris negotiations.

headline: DAMAGE IS ‘HEAVY’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 18—North Viet nam accused the United States today of resuming the air war north of the 20th Parallel with a heavy raid around Haiphong.

headline: Nixon Said to Weigh Steps To Put Pressure on Hanoi
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17— President Nixon is considering a number of diplomatic and military measures designed to put pressure on North Viet nam to reach an early cease fire agreement, well‐placed Ad ministration officials declared today.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Questions on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Henry A. Kissinger's an nouncement that the Vietnam peace talks had failed to reach “a just and fair agree ment” has raised, many unanswered questions. An article attempting to answer some appears on Page 3.

headline: Cooke, Forgoing Vietnam Trip, Says Mass for Ill Children Here
lead_paragraph: The patients in the pediatrics ward of a large East Side hos pital received a visit yester day from Cardinal Cooke, who celebrated a special mass, and a message of good cheer from the President of the United States.

headline: Pope Voices Sadness Over Peace Impasse
lead_paragraph: ROME, Dec. 17—Pope Paul VI voiced sadness and bitter ness today over the fact that “peace is not yet mature” in Indochina.

headline: U.S. Blamed for Impasse
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Mon day, Dec. 18 (Agence France Presse) — The official North Vietnamese party, newspaper to day blamed Washington for failure of the private talks in Paris between the United States and North Vietnam.

headline: Cambodian Air Stricks Reported
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 18 (Reuters)—Cambodian planes have bombed suspected concentrations of Vietnamese Communist troops within 16 miles of Phnom Penh, a mili tary command spokesman said today. He said T‐28, fighter‐ bombers struck last night and this morning, mainly against targets 12 miles northeast of the capital.

headline: Communists Hint Bombing May Bring Breakoff in Paris Talks
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 18—The Viet namese Communist delegations indicated tonight that remain ing private contacts with the Americans in Paris may be broken off now, that bombing of the North has resumed.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Bombs Away …
lead_paragraph: The best hope for peace in Indochina since 1954 hes been severely shaken by a hail of American bombs on Haiphong and the outskirts of Hanoi in a turn from negotiation once again to confrontation. Whatever else the resumed bombing of North Vietnam above the 20th Parallel may accomplish, it is not likely to hasten— and could indefinitely postpone—the “just and fair” agreement that Henry Kissinger has said is the Presi dent's objective.

headline: Street Calls Stock Reaction Emotional
lead_paragraph: Wall Street reacted yester day with words of caution in response to the disclosure of breakdown in the Vietnam peace talks and the subsequent sell‐off in the stock market.
author: By Terry Robards

headline: B‐52's Pound Hanoi Area 9 Miles From City Center
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 — American B‐52's bombed the northeast suburbs of Hanoi last night for the first time while fighter‐ bombers carried out an all‐ night raid—the heaviest and longest yet—against the city, it was announced.
author: By Jean Thoraval Agence France‐Presse

headline: A NEW TARGET LIST
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18— The Nixon Administratiod in nounced a resumption of full scale bombing and mining of North Vietnam today, and the White House warned that Such raids “will continue until such time as a settlement is arrifed at.”
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: …Deception or Naivete?
lead_paragraph: By their own wards, President Nixon and Mr. Kissin ger were either deceptive or naive in their pre‐election assurances to the American people about the imminence of peace in Vietnam. This is the sorry conclusion from the White House negotiator's remarkable briefing last Saturday.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany celebrated his 59th birthday in Bonn. Help ing Mr. Brandt celebrate were the Dilsseldorf Male Choir and Vice Chancellor Walter Scheel. With a touch of humor, Mr. Scheel gave Mr. Brandt a coin minted during the 19‐year joint rule in the 17th century of Dukes Ru dolf August and Anton Ulrich. The coin bore the motto “Duobus Fulcris Secu rius,” which can he trans lated to “It is surer to rule on the basis of two.” Mr. Scheel also joined the choir as it sang “When the Lilacs Blossom Again” for Mr. Brandt. The gift from the head of Mr. Brandt's politi cal opposition, Rainer Barzel, seemed simpler: 59 roses.

headline: U.S. Jets Hit Hanoi Area In 9 Waves Through Night
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Tues day, Dec. 19 — The Hanoi re gion was attacked by nine waves of United States bombers during the night.
author: By Jean Thoraval

headline: Haig Arrives in Saigon For Talks With Thies
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday Dec. 19 (Reuters)— President Nixon's deputy na tional‐security adviser, Gen. Aleicaridei M. Haig Jr., ar rived in Saigon today for talks with President Nguyen Van Thieu, a United States Embassy spokesman reported.

headline: Raids Termed Heaviest
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (AP) — Hun dreds—of United States war‐ planes, including B‐52 heavy bombers, resumed attacks last night above the 20th Parallel of North Vietnam. United States officials said the planes made the heaviest raids of the war against the Hanoi ‐ Haiphong area.

headline: AMEX AND O‐T‐C SHOW DECLINES
lead_paragraph: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over‐the counter market closed sharply lower yesterday as trading de clined.

headline: Third Day of Heavy righting Is Reported Around Quang Tri City
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (AP)— Heavy fighting was reported yesterday for the third day in the north ernmost part of SOuth. Vietnam near Quang Tri city.

headline: Red Cross Names Swede To Head Indochina Relief
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, Dec. 18—Oiof Stroh, secretary general of the Swedish Red Cross, will have over‐all charge of the relief operations that the interna tional Red Cross is planning across Indochina should a cease‐ fire end military operations, it was announced today.

headline: U.S. Says Departure of 300 Leaves 24,900 in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 (Reuters) — American troops strength in Vietnam dropped by 300 men last week to 24,900, the United States Command re ported today. A command spokeman said that the depart ing troops were soldiers and air men.

headline: A NEW TARGET LIST
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 — The Nixon Administration an nounced a resumption of full‐ schle bombing and mining of North Vietnam today, and the White House warned that such raids “will continue until such time as a settlement is arrived at.”
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Foe Said to Attack In Laos
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 18 (Reuters) — United States sources here reported today that North Vietnamese forces staged a rocket and infantry attack on the southern Laotian provincial capital of Saravane yesterday. But, they said, the attack was repulsed. No casu alty figures were available.

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (AP) — Hun dreds of United States war planes, including B‐52 heavy bombers, resumed attacks last night above the 20th Parallel of North Vietnam. United States officials said the planes made the heaviest raids of the war against the Hanoi ‐ Haiphong area.

headline: Foe Said to Attack In Laos
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 18 (Reuters) — United States sources here reported today that North Vietnamese forces staged a rocket and infantry attack on the southern Laotian provincial capital of Saravane yesterday. But, they said, the attack was repulsed. No casu alty figures were available.

headline: Haig Arrives in Saigon For Talks With Thieu
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (Reuters)— President Nixon's deputy na tional‐security adviser, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., ar rived in Saigon today for talks with President Nguyen Van Thieu, a United States Embassy spokesman reported.

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: The United States pulled 300 troops out of South Vietnam last week, low ering its strength there to 24,900, the smallest total since February 1965. Those with long memories and ironic minds will recall that February 1965 was the month when President John son began the bombing of North Viet nam in an effort to force the Hanoi Government to agree to American terms in the lethal dispute over the future of Indochina.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: LAVELLE'S RAIDS ARE HELD PROPER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)—A House subcommittee says the unauthorized Amer‐ ican air strikes ordered by Gen. John D. Lavelle against North Vietnam last winter “were not only proper but es sential.”

headline: Setback on Vietnam Spurs 13.99 Fall in Dow Index
author: By Vartanig G. Vartan

headline: 5 WAR FOES HELD IN RAIL SABOTAGE
lead_paragraph: YORK, Pa., Dec. 18 (AP)— Five antiwar activists were ar rested by the state police today for allegedly sabotaging rail road equipment near a factory that makes bomb casings used in the Vietnam war.

headline: Third Day of Heavy Fighting Is Reported Around Quang Tri City
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 19 (AP) — Heavy fighting was reported yesterday for the third day in the north ernmost part of South Vietnam near Quang Tri city.

headline: U.S. Says Departure of 300 Leaves 24,900 in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 18 (Reuters) — American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 300 men last week to 24,900, the United States command re ported today. A command spokeman said that the depart ing troops were soldiers and air men.

headline: Credit Markets
author: By Douglas W. Cray

headline: Thuy Puts Blame on U.S.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 19—North Viet nam's envoy placed “full re sponsibility” on the United States today for failure to reach a cease‐fire after almost a month of intense negotiations, but he carefully avoided saying there had been a rupture in the talks.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Thuy Puts Blame on U.S.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 19—North Viet nam's envoy placed “full re sponsibility” on the United States today for failure to reach a cease‐fire after almost a month of intense negotiations, but he carefully avoided saying there had been a rupture in the talks.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Kissinger's Deputy Meets Thieu, Then Lon Nol
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19—Henry A. Kissinger's deputy, Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., conferred with the leaders of South Vietnam and Cambodia today, with the an nounced purpose of explaining the state of the peace talks.

headline: Thuy Statement Denied
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. (Reuters)—The White House, Itook issue today with the statement by Xuan Thuy, chief of the North Vietnamese dele gation in Paris, that the United States had insisted on introduc ing 126 modifications to the tentative cease‐fire accord of Oct. 20.

headline: Haig Avoids Press
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 19—General Haig met with President Lon Nol today to bring him up to date on the impasse in the Vietnam nego tiations and presumably to reaf firm Washington's support and encouragement for Cambodia's struggle against North Vietna mese and local insurgent troops.

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19—In the aftermath of the break down of the Paris negotiations, and the renewed bombing of Hanoi and Haiphong, some diplomats, officials and news men are wondering aloud whether any possible strains have developed between Presi dent Nixon and his chief nego tiator and foreign policy ad viser, Henry A, Kissinger. The speculation is based on both rea sonable deduc lions and inlangi ble evidence. The rumors have been magnified by the current con fusion in Washington about almost everything dealing with Vietnam. Despite Mr. Kissin ger's news conference on Saturday, there is uncertainty about the reasons for the col lapse of the Paris talks, and the brief White House an nouncement yesterday about the bombing fell short of an explanation of why it was or dered.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Prices Decline on the Amex and O‐T‐C
lead_paragraph: The breakdown in the Viet nam peace talks announced on Saturday continued to have a depressing effect on prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over‐the‐counter market yesterday.

headline: Nixon Goal Held a ‘Fantasy’
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 19—North Vietnam accused the United States today of premedi tated intensification of the Viet nam war and termed the action insane.

headline: SHIPS POUND COAST
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 20—Two B‐52 heavy bombers and an F‐111 swing‐wing fighter‐bomber have been lost since the United States resumed full‐scale bomb ing of North Vietnam Monday, an American military spokes man said last night.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: 27th U.N. Assembly Ends; Results Prove to Be Mixed
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 19—The 27th annual ses sion of the General Assembly ended tonight with a mixed sense of accomplishment and failure.
author: By Robert Alden Special to The New York Times

headline: Peking Pledges Support
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Dec. 19 (AP)— China's Acting President, Tung Pi‐wu, and Premier Chou En lai have promised the Vietcong that “so long as the United States does not stop its war of aggression, the Chinese people will, as always, resolutely sup port and assist the just struggle of the Vietnamese people.”

headline: New U. S. Raids on North Are Denounced by Soviet
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 19—The Soviet Government today de nounced the resumption of wide‐scale United States air raids over North Vietnam and said it was giving the develop ing situation its “most serious consideration.”
author: By Theodore Shabad Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Displays 6 Prisoners
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 19 (Agence France‐Presse)—Six United States airmen, sonic of whom were said to be crew, members of a B‐52 bomber, were presented to the press here today. They were said to have been captured last night.

headline: Hanoi Displays 6 Prisoners
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 19 (Agence France‐Presse)—Six United States airmen, some of whom were said to be crew members of a B‐52 bomber, were presented to the press here today. They were said to have been captured last night.

headline: Hopes for Peace Dashed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19—The United States bombs that fell on Hanoi and Haiphong today brought gloom to many American officials here and jubilation to members of the South Vietnamese Govern ment.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: CONTINUED TALKS EXPECTED BY U.S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19— The White House said today that it expected low‐level tech nical talks on details of a set tlement in Vietnam to continue as scheduled this week in Paris despite the resumption of full scale bombing and mining of North Vietnam.
author: By Richard L. Madden Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 SAILORS KILLED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 20 — Three heavy B‐52 bombers and two smaller fighter‐bombers have been lost since the United States resumed full‐scale bomb ing and mining of North Viet nam Monday evening, an Amer ican military spokesman said today.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: NEW JERSEY
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 19— A group of 11 students and fac ulty members of the Princeton Theological Seminary today es tablished a defense fund for five antiwar activists arrested yesterday for allegedly sabotag ing railroad equipment outside a defense plant in York, Pa.

headline: DOW INDEX DROPS 4.07 MORE POINTS
lead_paragraph: The stock market sustained a second—and more modest— decline yesterday in the wake of the breakdown in Vietnam peace talks made public by American officials over the weekend.
author: By Vartanig G. Vartan

headline: Nixon and Kissinger and the Collapse of the Paris Peace Talks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19—In the aftermath of the break down of the Paris negotiations, and the renewed bombing of Hanoi and Haiphong, some diplomats, officials and news men are wondering aloud whether any possible strains have developed between Presi dent Nixon and his chief nego tiator and foreign policy ad viser, Henry A. Kissinger. The speculation is based on both rea sonable deduc tions and intangi ble evidence. The rumors have been magnified by the current con fusion in Washington about almost everything dealing with Vietnam. Despite Mr. Kissin ger's news conference on Saturday, there is uncertainty about the reasons for the col lapse of the Paris talks, and the brief White House an nouncement yesterday about the bombing fell short of an explanation of why it was or dered.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Reports 3 Ships Hit
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, Dec. 20 (AP)—The Hanoi radio said to day that three American war ships were “set ablaze” Sunday night off the port city of Thanh, Hoa.

headline: New U.S. Raids on North Are Denounced by Soviet
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 19—The Soviet Government today de nounced the resumption of wide‐scale United States air raids over North Vietnam and said it was giving the develop ing situation its “most serious consideration.”
author: By Theodore Shabad Special to The New York Times

headline: Hopes for Peace Dashed
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 19—The United States bombs that fell on Hanoi and Haiphong today brought gloom to many American officials here and jubilation to members of the South Vietnamese Govern ment.
author: By Sylvan Fox Special to The New York Times

headline: Other War Developments
lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union denounced the resumption of heavy American bombing of North Vietnam but did so in statement whose tone appeared to reflect embarrassment among Soviet leaders at the latest turn of events. The statement, by Tass, the official press agency, said that the Soviet people demanded that the raids be halted promptly and that an agreement be quickly signed end the war. [Page 14.]

headline: Nixon Goal Held a ‘Fantasy’
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 19—North Vietnam accused the United States today of premedi tated intensification of the Viet nam war and termed the action insane.

headline: Back to the Stone Age
lead_paragraph: With the opportunity safely to disengage American military personnel and prisoners from the Vietnamese conflict now rapidly receding, President Nixon has resort ed once more to naked force to try to obtain his own larger objectives in Southeast Asia—objectives which are neither realistic nor essential to this country's secu rity interests. However much Hanoi may be responsible for disrupting the negotiations—which is a highly dis puted point—civilized man will be horrified at the re newed spectacle of the world's mightiest air force merci lessly pounding a small Asian nation in an abuse national power and disregard of humanitarian principles.

headline: Nixon's Sincerity Doubted
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 19—The Soviet Ambassador to France, de nouncing the renewed bombing, today questioned the sincerity of American peace pledges de livered during President Nix on's visit to Moscow in the spring.

headline: Thuy Statement Denied
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (Reuters)—The White House took issue today with the statement by Xuan Thuy, chief of the North Vietnamese dele gation in Paris that the United States had insisted on introduc ing 126 modifications to the tentative cease‐fire accord of Oct. 20.

headline: Peking Pledges Support
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Dec. 19 (AP) — China's Acting President, Tung Pi‐wu, and Premier Chou En lai have promised the Vietcong that “so long as the United States does not stop its war of aggression, the Chinese people will, as always, resolutely sup port and assist the just struggle of the Vietnamese people.”

headline: Hanoi Halts Technical Talks in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 20 — North Vi etnam today announced the “postponement” of further talks here with the United States on technical details of a Vietnam cease‐fire.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: Concessions by Both Sides Reported Urged by Nixon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 21—Official South Vietnamese sources said today that President Nixon had urged both North Vietnam and South Vietnam to make con cessions toward a peace settle ment.

headline: Is Prosperity at Hand?
lead_paragraph: The stock market has registered its disappointment at fading hopes for an early peace settlement in Vietnam. In three days the Dow‐Jones industrial average has dropped more than 22 points, and now threatens to under the 1,000 mark it attained soon after President Nixon's re‐election.

headline: Arrives in Vientiane
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 20— General Haig spent an hour and 15 minutes with the Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phou ma, today, briefing him on the impasse in the Paris peace negotiations.

headline: Hanoi Reports Casualties
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20 (AP) — The Hanoi radio reported today that 215 persons were killed and 325 were wounded in the North Vi etnamese capital in raids on Monday and yesterday. In Hai phong, it added, 45 persons were killed and 131 wounded on Monday.

headline: Senate Leaders Differ
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) —The Republican leader of the Senate said today that Presi dent Nixon's bombing decision should be supported, but his Democratic counterpart said that it would only prolong the war.

headline: PENTAGON SAYS BOMBINGS WRECK MILITARY TARGETS; IT DENIES ‘TERROR’ RAIDS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20—The Defense Department said today that the intensive American bombing of North Vietnam in the last two clays had caused “very significant damage” to a broad range of military targets.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Airport Guards Shot
lead_paragraph: A Vietnam veteran who had been confined for mental illness shot and wounded two Federal security officers yes terday at Kennedy Interna tional Airport before being captured, the police said. De tails on Page 70.

headline: Stock Prices Off Again On Stalemate in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Stock prices continued to decline yesterday in reaction to stalemated peace efforts and a resumption of full‐scale bombing and mining of North Vietnam. Statistically, the market was a virtual replay of Tuesday's performance. The Dow‐Jones industrial average slipped 4.36 points to 1,004.82 and declines outpaced ad vances on the New York Stock Exchange by a 9‐to‐5 ratio.
author: By Vartanig G. Vartan

headline: Much European Criticism
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP)— President Nixon's bombing de cision produced criticism today in much of Europe and espe cially in the Nordic countries. In Finland, where criticism of United States policies in Vietnam has been muted in the past, Foreign Minister Ahti Karjalainen declared: “It is es pecially difficult to understand on what arguments the vast bombardment of the North Vietnamese territory has been based.”

headline: Polish Tell of Attack
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Dec. 20 (Reuters) —A Polish freighter was sunk and three Polish seamen were killed in an American bombing attack on the North Vietnamese port of Haiphong today, the Polish press agency reported.

headline: Pope Deplores Bombing
lead_paragraph: ROME, Dec. 20—Pope Paul VI today deplored the resumption of United States bombing deep in North Vietnam and called for patient negotiations to seek peace.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Concessions by Both Sides Reported Urged by Nixon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Doc. 21—Official South Vietnamese sources said today that President Nixon had urged both North Vietnam and South Vietnam to make con cessions toward a peace settle ment.

headline: HANOI iS BLAMED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20—The Defense Department said today that the intensive American bombing of North Vietnam in the last two days had caused “very significant damage” to a broad range of military targets.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. REPORTS LOSS OF A FOURTH B‐52
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 21—A United States military spokesman dis closed this morning that a fourth B‐52 Stratofortress was struck by antiaircraft fire and crashed late last night as what is believed to be the heaviest bombing of the war apparently continued in North Vietnam.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: In Capitals, Bombing Draws Protests, Some Support
lead_paragraph: As waves of American planes continued to sweep over North Vietnam, new protests were voiced in many parts of the world yesterday against Presi dent Nixon“s decision to re sume the heavy attacks, but there were also some expres sions of support.

headline: SAIGON REPORTS ON TWO BATTLES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 21 (UPI) — Heavy ground fighting was re ported yesterday on South Viet nam's northernmost front, with two battles fought near Quang Tri city.

headline: Last of Australians Home From Vietnam To Muted Welcome
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 —The last Australian troops in Vietnam came home today to muted welcome, ending a 10‐ year commitment that had divided the nation.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodia Endorses Move
lead_paragraph: Special to The New York TimesPHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 20—The Cambodian Gov ernment today endorsed the re sumption of full‐scale bombing of North Vietnam by the United States as a necessary step to force Hanoi to adopt a more conciliatory attitude at the negotiating table.

headline: Meets That Premier Today
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 20 (AP)—General Haig arrived. in Bangkok from Vientiane to day.

headline: Two Airport Guards at Kennedy Shot; Veteran Seized in Struggle on a Ramp
lead_paragraph: A Vietnam veteran who had twice fled Rockland State Hos pital after confinement for men tal illness shot and wounded two Federal security officers at Kennedy International Air port yesterday with a gun grabbed from one of the guards, the police reported.
author: By Richard Witkin

headline: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 20—Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. met for half an hour today with President Nguyen Van Thieu. It was General Haig's second meeting with Mr. Thieu since he arrived here yes terday.

headline: Soviet Urges Speedy Truce
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 20—The So viet Union reiterated today its call for a speedy signing by Washington of the cease‐fire accord negotiated in Paris last October.

headline: Administration Aides Insist That Hanoi Is Solely to Blame for Talk Breakdown
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 — Administration officials insisted today that North Vietnam was entirely to blame for the break down in the Vietnam talks and said that the United States had resumed heavy bombing be cause of Hanoi's lack of “seri ousness” at the Paris negotiations.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Airport Guards Shot
lead_paragraph: A Vietnam veteran who had been confined for mental illness shot and wounded two Federal security officers yes terday at Kennedy Interna tional Airport before being captured, the police said. De tails on Page 70.

headline: China Denounces Move
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Dec. 20—China ac cused the United States today of having committed “a new barbarous crime” with its in tensified bombing of North Vietnam and declared that it would never succeed in impos ing peace terms unacceptable to Hanoi.

headline: Harbor First Developed by French
lead_paragraph: Situated 60 miles southeast of Hanoi on the Cua Cam, an arm of the Thai Binh River, which flows into the Gulf of Tonkin, Haiphong is the principal port of North Vietnam and as such a target of vital importance.

headline: Cultural and Manufacturing Center
lead_paragraph: Hanoi, which stands beside the Red River, is a port, railroad and industrial center whose population has in creased from 120,000 to about 500,000 in 30 years.

headline: Hanoi Charges Insolence
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 (AP) — North Vietnam said tonight that it would not he intimidated by a reported ulti matum from President Nixon to sign a peace agreement or face continued heavy air and naval attacks.

headline: 11 IN CONGRESS URGE ANTIBOMBING STAND
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) —The House Democratic cau cus will he asked at its Jan. 2 meeting before the opening of the new Congress to go on record against the renewed bombing of North Vietnam, it was announced today.

headline: All‐Out Attack Reported
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 21 (Reuters)—The Cam bodian command said today that. North Vietnamese forces began an all‐out attack last night on Kompong Thom, the provincial capital 77 miles north of here that has been under siege since Dec. 7.

headline: Excerpts From the Kremlin Address of Soviet Leader
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 21—Fol lowing, in official translation, are excerpts front an address by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the So viet Communist party leader, at a celebration in the Kremlin Hall of Congresses today in honor of the 50th anniversary of the formation of the Soviet Union:

headline: One American Died in War Last Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 21 (AP)—The United States command announced today that one American was killed in ac tion and six were wounded in Indochina last week.

headline: Ground Action Light Except in the Region Around Quang Tri
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Dec. 22 (AP)—Major fight ing reportedly continued yes terday in the northernmost part of South Vietnam, but elsewhere in the country, ac tion on the ground was said to he at a low level.

headline: A French Comment
lead_paragraph: PARIS—There was a time not very long ago when one Guernica, while not actually provoking an offensive against barbarity, caused nausea in the West when the West discovered it was capable of the worst against mankind. It was already a case of air planes massacring a civilian popula tion, a case of airplanes dispatched by a foreign power to support dic tatorship.

headline: Brezhnev Links Relations With U.S. to War's End
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 21—Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, condemning the renewed American air war against Hanoi and Haiphong, declared today that the future development of Soviet‐Ameri can relations hinged largely on what happened on the issue of ending the Vietnam war.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: TRAFFIC DISRUPTED IN ANTIWAR PROTEST
lead_paragraph: A thousand demonstrators protesting against the renewed bombing of North Vietnam poured into Times Square last night and disrupted traffic in termittently for nearly two hours.

headline: COUNT SHARES OFF FOR 4TH DAY
lead_paragraph: The over‐the‐counter market and the American Stock Ex change posted their fourth con secutive losing day yesterday in active trading.

headline: Chinese Ship Reported Hit
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Friday, Dec. 22 —China charged today that a Chinese merchant vessel was struck and damaged by United States planes bombing Hai phong yesterday and issued a strong protest over the incident.

headline: Mystery of Bombing in the North
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Brezhnev Links Relations With U.S. to War's End
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 21—Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, condemning the renewed American air war against Hanoi and Haiphong, declared today that the future development of Soviet‐Ameri can relations hinged largely on what happened on the issue of ending the Vietnam war.
author: By Hedrick Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Tass Reports on Raids
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 22— Official North Vietnamese fig ures put the casualty toll from American air raids around Hanoi at 215 dead and 326 wounded through noon Tues day, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

headline: Capital Sources Differ
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 — Congressional sources close to the Senate Armed Services Committee said today that they had been informed by Pentagon officials that a total of 13 B‐52's had been lost thus far in the current series of raids against North Vietnam.

headline: The U.S.S.R.'s 50th
lead_paragraph: It was a wide‐ranging speech that Leonid I. Brezhnev delivered yesterday to mark the fiftieth birthday of the formation of the Soviet Union as the world now knows it. Kremlinologists will note that Mr. Brezhnev chose to hold the celebration nine days early, on Stalin's birthday.

headline: The Rhetoric of Peace
lead_paragraph: PARIS—It is with dismay that we read that most Americans think that the war in Vietnam is almost over and that Mr. Nixon is making every effort for peace. Our daily news from Viet nam tells of suffering at its worst in ten years, yet the human reality of the war continues to be ignored not only by governments and war‐makers, but by most men and women in the United States.
author: By Thich Nhat Hanh

headline: 4 MORE B‐52'S LOST IN THE HANOI AREA AS BIG RAIDS GO ON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 22—A United States spokesman said today that four more B‐52 heavy bombers were shot down near Hanoi yester day, raising to eight the num ber lost since Monday.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Joan Baez Performs At a Service in Hanoi
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 21 (Agence France Presse) — Twelve captured American pilots last night at tended a special Christmas service held by a visiting Yale University theologian and fea turing Joan Baez, the folk singer and antiwar activist.

headline: COMMUNISTS QUIT SESSION IN PARIS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 21—The North Vietnamese and Vietcong dele gates walked out of the formal Paris conference today to pro test the intensive United States bombing. But they called for another regular meeting next Thursday.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: 4 MORE B‐52'S LOST IN THE HANOI AREA AS BIG RAIDS GO ON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Dec. 22—A United States spokesman said today that four more B‐52 heavy bombers were shot down near Hanoi yester day, raising to eight the num ber lost since Monday.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: COMMUNISTS QUIT SESSION IN PARIS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 21—The North Vietnamese and Vietcong dele gates walked out of the formal Paris conference today to pro test the intensive United States bombing. But they called for another regular meeting next Thursday.
author: By Flora Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: DOW HEX SLIPS TO CLOSE AT 1,000
lead_paragraph: The stalemated peace in Vietnam continued to cast its shadow over Wall Street yes terday as the Dow‐Jones in dustrial average slipped 4.82 to close at an even 1,000.
author: By Vartanig G. Vartan

headline: Terror From the Skies
lead_paragraph: Asked whether civilian centers would not inevitably be hit during the resumed massive air assault on North Vietnam, a Pentagon spokesman replied: “No. We don't strike civilian targets.” He then amended his comment to say: “We do not target civilian targets.”

headline: Laotian Victory Reported
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 21 (UPI)—Informed sources said today that Government troops, supported by AC‐47 gunships, repelled a North Vietnamese at tack last night on positions half a mile south of the southern Laotian town of Saravane.

headline: Haig Briefs Thai Leaders On Status of Peace Effort
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 21 (Reuters) — Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's en voy, today met with the Thai Premier, Field Marshal Thanom Kittikachorn, and other Thai leaders and explained develop ments in the recent negoti ations between the United States and North Vietnam.

headline: Letter to Thieu Confirmed
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 21 (UPI) — The President's personal envoy, Gen. Alexan der M. Haig Jr., carried a let ter from Mr. Nixon to Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu the White House confirmed today, declining to disclose its con tents.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 22—When the Lord told Abraham that He was going to destroy Sodom for its sins, as it is said in Genesis, Chapter 18, Abraham asked, “Wilt thou also destroy the righteous with the wicked?” The Lord agreed that if there were ten righteous men In Sodom, “then I will spare all the place for their sakes.” But there were not ten.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: A Sixth Day of Big Raids
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 23—As the United States continued its heavy bombing of North Viet nam today for the sixth day, the officially reported losses of American planes and crewmen mounted still higher.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: U. S. to Continue Bombing; Says Next Move Is Hanoi's
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22—The White House said today that the United States would con tinue its heavy bombing of North Vietnam and that the next step to end the Vietnam war was “totally” up to the North Vietnamese.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Urge End to War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22— Forty‐one religious leaders in the United States have issued a pastoral letter assailing United States bombing of North Viet nam, it was announced today.

headline: LARGEST HOSPITAL IN HANOI REPORTED DAMAGED IN RAID
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 22—Ha noi's largest hospital, one mile west of the city center, was damaged by American planes early today, according to the Swedish Foreign Ministry.

headline: Laos Drug Curb Hailed But Outflow Continues
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 22— As part of a recently initiated campaign by the United States and Laotian Governments to crack down on narcotics traf fic in and through Laos, Pre mier Souvanna Phouma and the American Ambassador opened a new addict detoxifica tion center here today.
author: By Malcolm W. Browne Special to The New York Times

headline: India Protests Damage
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, Dec. 22 (Reuters) — Indian diplomatic quarters in Hanoi were dam aged by American bombing yes terday and India has delivered a strong protest to the United States, parliament was told to day.

headline: New Bombing Revives Antiwar Protests
lead_paragraph: Scattered protests, expres sions of outrage and signs of a reanimated antiwar movement have surfaced here and in cities across the country this week in response to the renewed American bombing of North Vietnam.

headline: A Sixth Day of Big Raids
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Dec. 23 — As the United States continued its heavy bombing of North Viet nam today for the sixth clay, the officially reported losses of American B‐52 bombers rose to 10 and the number of missing airmen rose to at least 55.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Identifies 5
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Saturday, Dec. 23 (UPI) — The Hanoi radio gave the names today of five more Americans it said had been cap tured after bombing raids over North Vietnam.

headline: U. S. to Continue Bombing; Says Next Move Is Hanoi's
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22—The White House said today that the United States would con tinue its heavy bombing of North Vietnam and that the next step to end the Vietnam war was “totally” up to the North Vietnamese.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Plans One‐Day Christmas Truce
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Dec. 23 (AP)—The South Vietnamese Government today announced a 24‐hour cease‐fire for Christmas.

headline: Questions ‘Painful Delay’
lead_paragraph: ROME, Dec. 22 — Pope Paul VI said today that the reasons for the break in the Vietnam peace talks were not “suffi ciently apparent.”
author: By Paul Hofmann Special to The New York Times

headline: Urge End to War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22— Forty‐one religious leaders in the United States have issued a, pastoral letter assailing United States bombing of North Viet nam, it was announced today.

headline: Mrs. Binh Assails U.S.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (Reuters) —Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, the chief Vietcong delegate to the four‐party peace talks at Paris, charged today that the United States was demanding revision of major points in the tentative cease‐fire agreement reached with North Vietnam.

headline: Questions ‘Painful Delay’
lead_paragraph: ROME, Dec. 22 —Pope Paul VI said today that the reasons for the break in the Vietnam peace talks were not “suffi ciently apparent.”
author: By Paul Hofmann Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Says Normal Life Goes on Despite Bombs
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Dec. 22 (Reu ters)—North Vietnam said to day that American bombing had not disrupted the normal life of Hanoi.

headline: Joint Attack in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Dec. 22 (Reuters)—The Cam bodian command said today that an unspecified number of its troops began an operation with South Vietnamese troops yesterday, with the aim of clear ing a Communist‐occupied area of Cambodia 55 miles south of here.

headline: General Giap Says Hanoi Will Win Despite Rombing
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 22—Gen, Vo Nguyen Giap, North Vietnam's Defense Min ister and leading military stra tegist, has declared that Hanoi and Haiphong may be “erased” by United States bombs, but that in the end the North Viet namese will win the war.

headline: Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—This was to have been the week when Henry A. Kis singer's peace pledge of Oct. 26 would be translated into agreement, making Christmas truly joyous for all those in this country and the world who direct ly or indirectly have borne the burdens of the Vietnam war. Instead, Wash ington this Christmas was steeped in gloom. Even the official Government spokesmen did not seem to have their hearts in their work. For instead of peace they could only project more war.
author: Bernard Gwertzman

headline: SECRECY IS TIGHT
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Dec. 24—Heavy Amer ican bombing of North Vietnam continued for a seventh day to day while the United States military command drew even tighter its curtain of secrecy over the operation.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Airport Reported Hard Hit
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 23— A flight that was to have brought Soviet Cosmonaut Ger man Titov to Hanoi and to have departed with four Americans who have been there for the past week has been postponed.

headline: Which America?
lead_paragraph: In the same week that American astronauts fired their spacecraft home from the moon, American pilots fired bombs that broke through the heavens over a peasant nation in Asia. America the ingenious and America the vengeful had both struck.

headline: New Novel
lead_paragraph: The “ears” of the jungle are a sophisticated network of sen sors designed by the American forces to pick up the sounds of truck convoys on the Ho Chi Minh Trail. But the foreign devils have reckoned without the resourcefulness of “Aunt” Ngha, the intelligence chief for Uncle Ho, President of the Democratic Republic of North Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John Khanlian

headline: More than 50,000 Americans killed in Vietnam, more than 300,000 wounded or injured, more than 1,600 P.O.W.'s or M.I.A.'s
lead_paragraph: The issue generates strong emotions across the country. How, some ask, can amnesty be offered to those who fled when others fought? But, others assert, how can amnesty not be offered to those who were right about the war before the rest of us?
author: By Julius Duscha

headline: CIVIL RULE ASKED FOR PACIFICATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23—The State Department has recom mended the virtual elimination of the Defense Department's role in pacification efforts in South Vietnam.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Europe Reacts to Bombing With Increasing Protests
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 23—Western Europe is reacting to the Amer ican bombing of North Vietnam with growing protests and a mixture of sadness, disgust and anger.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
lead_paragraph: THE GLOOM and uncertainty lately created by the stalemate in the Vietnam peace negotiations and the sudden resumption of heavy American bombing in southeast Asia have marred what could have been a truly joyous season in the business and economic world.
author: By Thomas E. Mullaney

headline: Vietnam
author: SPECIAL TO THE NEW YORK TIMES

headline: P.O.W. Casualties Reported
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP)— Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported from Hanoi today that American air strikes over the North Vietnamese capital had inflicted casualties on Ameri can pilots held prisoner there.

headline: B‐52 Vindicates Its Role, Air Force Aides Assert
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23—Air Force officials believe that the aging B‐52 has, in the last few days, redeemed its role as a strategic bomber capable of penetrating the Soviet Union.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Waldheim Voices Concern
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 23 (Reuters) — Secretary General Waldheim said today that he was greatly concerned at the continued United States bombing of North Vietnam.

headline: Thuy Asserts U.S. Raised Objections Of Thieu in Talks
lead_paragraph: Xuan Thuy, head of the North Vietnamese delegation to the Paris peace talks, said in an interview last week that before the negotiations broke down Henry A. Kissinger had raised in the private talks all the public demands made by President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam, the American Broadcasting Company reported last night.

headline: Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—“During the 24 hour pe riod ending at 0800 today, U.S. crews conducted bombing operations against military targets in North Viet nam.” With that bland announcement, the American command last week launched the heaviest air attacks of the entire war against the North.
author: Fox Butterfield

headline: Children of G.I.'s Shunned in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 (Reuters) — John and Gigi are two children of mixed parentage in one of South Viet nam's numerous overcrowded orphanages.

headline: A Hanoi Battalion in Laos Said to Seize Key Bridge
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 23— Military sources reported today that North Vietnamese troops backed by tanks had captured an important bridgehead in southern Laos only 15 miles from the Thai border.
author: By Malcolm W. Browne Special to The New York Times

headline: MARKETS IN REVIEW
lead_paragraph: The stock market nosedived last week in a decisive reaction to Henry A. Kissinger's disclosure of a break down in the Vietnam peace negotiations. Heavy selling moved in Monday and continued until Friday.
author: By Allen McKee

headline: Report on Giap Doubted
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 23—American intelligence officials denied any knowledge today of a report by some South Vietnamese in telligence sources that General Vo Nguyen Giap, the North Vietnamese Defense Minister, had been killed in the Hanoi Haiphong area.

headline: And Is This to Be America's Hell?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America's peace was at hand. Peace still is at hand but it is not being grasped.
author: By Leslie H. Gelb and Anthony Lake

headline: HOSPITAL DEATHS
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 23—The North Vietnamese Vice Minister of Health said tonight that 25 doctors, pharmacists and male and female nurses had been killed at Bach Mai Hospital during American bomb ing raids on Hanoi in the last few days.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: J. C. Phillips

headline: TECHNICAL TALKS BREAK OFF IN PARIS
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 23—A meeting of delegates who are assigned to discuss technical aspects of the Vietnam peace negotiations was adjourned abruptly today.

headline: Hanoi Says Friedheim Lied
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23 (AP)—The Hanoi radio said today that the American De fense Department spokesman, Jerry W. Friedheim, was lying when he said that American bombers were not targeting any areas in which the Penta gon believed that United States prisoners of war were being held.

headline: Saigon Still Demanding Hanoi Pullout, Aide Says
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 23—Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam reiterated today his Gov ernment's demand that all North Vietnamese troops must be withdrawn from South Vietnam before a peace accord would be acceptable to Saigon.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Bob Hope Performs For G.I.'s and Says It's His Final Tour.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 24 — Bob Hope, a substitute Santa for two decades of G.I.'s, gave what he said was his last annual Christmas show in Viet nam today, adding that he had originally thought that he might be able to perform it in Hanoi for American prisoners.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Nixon Ignores Protesters
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 24 (UPI)—President Nixon ig nored antiwar demonstrators outside his vacation home today and settled down for a quiet holiday with his wife.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 24—The only bless ing we can really hope for on Christ mas is self‐perception. Miracles are not to be expected: only the chance of seizing on the symbol of Christmas to look within and see who we are. That was what the Spirits did for Scrooge in done night.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: TEMPORARY HALT IN RAIDS ON NORTH BY U.S. REPORTED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 25—Informed American military officers said this morning that the United States had at least temporarily halted the bombing of North Vietnam.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Is Reported Scarred But Key Services Continue
lead_paragraph: The following dispatch, which was delayed in trans mission, was written by Telford Taylor, professor of law at Columbia University, who is visiting Hanoi with group of Americans. Mr. Taylor, a retired brigadier gen eral, was chief prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crimes trials and is the author of several books, including “Nurem berg and Vietnam: An American Tragedy.”

headline: Thuy Rejects Peace Talks While U.S. Raids Continue
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 — Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's negotiator at the regular Paris talks on Vietnam, said in an interview made public today, that his Government would not resume negotiations with the United States as long as the Nixon Administration con tinued bombing north of the 20th Parallel.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Christmas Eve Crowds Throng Central Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 24 — For several hours this evening vehicular traffic was barred in the heart of Saigon as thousands of resi dents—young couples, fami lies with small children and swarms of teen‐age boys — strolled through the streets in their best clothes.

headline: TEMPORARY HALT IN RAIDS ON NORTH BY U.S. REPORTED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 25—Informed Anterican military officers said this morning that the United States had at least temporarily halted the bombing of North Vietnam.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Spirit of Goodwill Ushers In Christmas
lead_paragraph: In city towers and shabby tenements, in light‐strung sub urban homes and in prisons, hospitals and churches across the metropolitan area, families and friends gathered on an overcast eve of Christmas last night to exchange gifts and thoughts of goodwill.
author: By Robert D. McFadden

headline: NEW JERSEY
lead_paragraph: 3 Killed When Car Overturns

headline: Thieu Orders 93 Released
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 24 (UPI) — President Nguyen Van Thieu ordered the release of 93 convicts and commuted the sentences of 137 others in his annual Christmas clemency, message today, the Govern ment announced. None granted clemency were political pris oners.

headline: Thuy Rejects Peace Talks While U.S. Raids Continue
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 — Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's negotiator at the regular. Paris talks on Vietnam, said in an interview made public today that his Government would not resume negotiations with the United States as long as the Nixon Administration con tinued bombing north of the 20th Parallel.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: PAUSE IN BOMBING OF NORTH VIETNAM SAID TO CONTINUE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 26 — Informed American military officers said early today that the pause in bombing of North Vietnam that began on Christmas eve re mained in effect past midnight. They added that they had re ceived no indication of when the air raids might be resumed.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: HAMLET, N. C., Dec. 25—The bar baric bombing we Americans are in ??ting on a faraway nation of Asia does not echo loudly here in this small Southern town, where few see the Eastern liberal press that President. Nixon so disdains. Television news on the local channel provides more of the natural devastation in Managua than of the American‐made havoc in Hanoi.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: U.S. RENEWS RAIDS IN NORTH VIETNAM AFTER LULL ENDS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 26 — United States bombers resumed at tacks in North Vietnam above the 20th Parallel this afternoon after a 36‐hour suspension of strikes for Christmas, the United States command an nounced.

headline: Silent Protest in London
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP)— Two hundred legislators, cler ics, union leaders and actors lined the pavements outside the American Embassy in London today in silent protest against the renewed bombing.

headline: March in Berlin
lead_paragraph: BERLIN, Dec. 25 (UN) — Several hundred demonstrators shouting “Nixon murderer” marched down the Kurfürsten damm, West Berlin's main street, today to protest United States policy in Vietnam. A police spokesman said five persons had been arrested for carrying stones.

headline: WAR PROTEST HELD NEAR WHITE HOUSE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UPI) —Chanting “Stop the bomb ing, Lord,” about 200 people took Christmas communion in an interfaith service for peace today across the street from the White House.

headline: 500 Hail Carrier on Return
lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 25 (UPI)—About 500 relatives and friends and one Santa Claus were on hand in the morning fog today to offer a holiday greeting to the men of the attack carrier U.S.S. Oki nawa, returning from a nine‐ month tour in the Western Pa cific and off Vietnam.

headline: The Earlier Reports
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Dec. 26 — Informed American military officers said early today that the pause in bombing of North Vietnam that began on Christmas Eve re mained in effect past midnight.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: American Force in Vietnam Now 24,200, a Drop of 700
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 25 (UPI) — American military strength in Vietnam declined to 24.200 last week, a drop of 700 men from the previous week and the lowest total in almost eight years, the United States command said today.

headline: Issue and Debate
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25— The resumption of sustained bombing by the United States throughout North Vietnam has revived the debate here and abroad over the efficacy of the bombing strategy.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Reports Heavy Toll
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 25 (Agence France‐Presse) — The North Vietnamese press agency reported today that American planes killed or wounded thousands in the Hanoi and Haiphong raids be tween Dec. 18 and Dec. 24 and that 40,000 tons of bombs were dropped on North Vietnam.

headline: Jersey Leader Picketed
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Dec. 25 (AP)—The home of Harry L. Sears, the New Jersey campaign chairman for Mr. Nixon, was picketed here this morning by about 75 Morris County peace activists.

headline: Truce Violations Charged
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Dec. 25 (AP)—The South Vietnamese command to day reported 58 violations dur ing overlapping 24‐hour cease fires set by the Vietcong and the Saigon Government. Each side blamed the other for the violations.

headline: Gus Hall Sees ‘Swindle’
lead_paragraph: Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist Party, U.S.A., said yesterday that President Nixon was “guilty of political treachery without precedent” and “never intended to sign” the Vietnam peace agreement. The President's adviser, Henry A. Kissinger, added to Mr. Nix on's “swindle,” Mr. Hall de clared, when he said the North Vietnamese “wanted to change the agreement,” The Associated Press reported.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba made one of his rare, as far as is known, toboggan rides. It happened in the snows of Gander, Newfound land, while the plane taking the Premier home from Mos cow was refueling. The Pre mier laughed as he fell off the toboggan. And, judging from photographs of the event, some of those in the area of the fall laughed, too. There was no indication whether Mr. Castro had any snow fun in Moscow, which he had just visited for the second time in 1972.
author: James F. Clarity

headline: NEW U.S. BOMBING ASSAILED BY HANOI
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 26—North Viet nam denounced today the re sumption of American bombing of Hanoi but indicated it was willing to resume negotiation if the attacks halted.

headline: Flight From Hanoi Canceled
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, Dec. 26— A. flight to and from Hanoi scheduled today by the three‐ nation International Control Commission was canceled at the last moment because of a radio communication from the con trol tower at Hanoi's Gia Lam Airport, saying it would be un safe to land.

headline: U.S. SAYS BOMBING IS BACK AT LEVEL PRECEDING PAUSE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 27—With its 36‐hour pause in the bombing of North Vietnam ended, the United States command said yesterday that the planes were once again operating as they had last week, when the raids were the heaviest of the war.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘And This Should Outrage the Conscience of All Americans’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—In recent weeks President Nixon has had another op portunity to end the Indochina tragedy and accomplish the return of our pris oners of war — on a basis which would have had the support and praise of all Americans. But events suggest a return to the same old war. For we cannot read about the heavy bombing, the new targets, and the unprece dented loss of American pilots and planes, without a deep and despairing sense that peace is not at hand.
author: By Edward M. Kennedy

headline: Bombing and the Outlook for Business
lead_paragraph: Economic Analysis
author: By Leonard Silk

headline: U.S. SAYS BOMBING IS BACK AT LEVEL PRECEDING PAUSE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Dec. 27—With its 36‐hour pause in the bombing of North Vietnam ended, the United States command said yesterday that the planes were once again operating as they had last week, when the raids were the heaviest of the war.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Raid on Hanoi Called Heaviest in War
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 26 (Agence France‐Presse)— American bombers tonight con ducted the most violent air at tack on Hanoi since the begin ning of the war.

headline: U.S. Calls Raids Major Effort
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26—A Pentagon spokesman said today the air war against Hanoi and Haiphong had resumed and “continues to be a very major effort.”

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26—President Nixon has sent the bombers over North Vietnam again, but it is hard to see how this air war can go on for long at the present rate.
author: By James Reston

headline: SWEDISH COMMENT BRINGS U.S. PROTEST
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (Reu ters)—The United States has strongly protested to Sweden over Premier Olof Palme's statement Saturday comparing the United States bombing of Hanoi to Nazi massacres in World War II, a State Depart ment spokesman said today. The Swedish Ambassador, Hu bert de Besche, was called to the department Saturday by Acting Secretary of State U. Alexis Johnson and was given the oral protest.

headline: DA NANG BASE AREA IS HIT BY 35 ROCKETS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, Dec. 27 (UPI)—Communist gunners fired 35 rockets into the Ameri can‐Vietnamese air base at Da Nang and surrounding civilian areas just before dawn Monday. One American was slightly wounded and two Vietnamese civilians were killed. Five Amer ican helicopters were damaged or destroyed at the base, which is 370 miles north of Saigon. The attack was the first against the base since Dec. 3.

headline: What to Do?
lead_paragraph: America's bombs sear through North Vietnam's cities and countryside again, perhaps even touching some of the camps where a tragically increasing company of American war prisoners sit helplessly. After a brief obeisance to Christmas, the spirit of war has re‐emerged untempered. Does the muted popular outcry against the renewed massive bombardments indicate that the Admin istration's grievous policy is having a grievous conse quence here at home: the apathetic withdrawal of con cerned citizens and their representatives in Congress into a mood of hopelessness and resignation? It needn't and mustn't be.

headline: Bengalis Burn U.S. Office To Protest Vietnam Bombing
lead_paragraph: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 26 (AP) — Students protesting against the bombing of North Vietnam set fire today to the United States Information Cen ter at Rajashahi, 90 miles north west of here, and caused con siderable damage.

headline: White House Is Silent
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP)—The White House maintained silence on the re sumption of bombing attacks on North Vietnam today fol lowing the vain wait by Presi dent Nixon for a peace signal from Hanoi.

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, Dec. 27 (Reu ters)—About 100 demonstra tors gathered outside the United States Embassy here today to protest the resumed American bombing of North Vietnam.

headline: On Resuming the Bombing
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: (Prof.) Earl Miner

headline: U.S. LISTS TARGETS OF HEAVY ATTACKS IN NORTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 28 — The United States military com mand, breaking a nine‐day si lence on damage inflicted in the intensive American air attacks against North Vietnam, listed nearly three dozen airfields, rail yards, power plants, supply depots and communications centers yesterday among the facilities that have been bombed.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: On Resuming the Bombing
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Margaret B. Morse

headline: AUSTRALIA HALTS SAIGON ARMS AID
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 27 —Australia stopped military aid to South Vietnam today, ending the last vestige of this country's controversial partici pation in the Vietnam war.
author: By Robert Trumbull Special to The New York Times

headline: ALLIED PLANE KILLS 9 IN A BOMBING ERROR
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 27 (AP) — A South Viet namese F‐5 fighter‐bomber ac cidentally dropped a bomb in village 20 miles northeast of Saigon today, killing nine ci vilians and wounding 10, re ports from the area said. Six homes were reported destroyed.

headline: U.S. to Seek Clarification
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. (Reu ters) — State Department offi cials were taken by surprise to day by the Australian Govern ment's decision to halt military aid to South Vietnam.

headline: Poles List 4th Bomb Death
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Dec. 27 (AP) —A fourth Polish seaman has died in a Haiphong hospital as a result of injuries suffered in a United States air strike last week, the official Polish press agency said today. The Polish Government reported earlier that three Poles had been killed when their cargo ship, the Jo seph Conrad, was struck and sunk.

headline: The Longest War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—One of the primary reasons this tragic war continues is because a majority of the Congress has consistently refused to confront the executive branch with obvious in consistencies in its various statements about Vietnam.
author: By Stuart Symington

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: The late Harry S. Truman, who was anything but a cry‐baby like the pres ent incumbent of the White House, is famous for having said that “if you can't stand the heat, you better get out of the kitchen.” He also observed, almost jovially, that “whenever the press quits abusing me, I know I'm in the wrong pew.” That was in the middle of the 1948 campaign and Mr. Truman knew better than most that while the editorial writers and column ists were mostly against him, the front‐page headlines that reflected his “give 'em hell” style were working for him.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: Speak Up, Mr. President
lead_paragraph: Despite the communiqué tardily issued in Saigon yes terday, the Nixon Administration continues to evade the toughest and most pertinent questions about the mas sive new United States air assault against North Vietnam.

headline: On Resuming the Bombing
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Lester E. Waterbury

headline: Witness in Kitty Hawk Hearing Charges That Whites Beat Black Officer in October Rioting on Carrier
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 27 — A black crewman of the aircraft carrier Kitty. Hawk testified at a Navy hearing today that he had seen white sailors knock down and beat the ship's executive officer during racial rioting aboard the carrier off the coast of Vietnam.

headline: VATICAN DENIES POPE SENT PLEA TO NIXON
lead_paragraph: ROME, Dec. 27—Two leading Italian newspapers — Corriere Della Sera of Milan and Il Mes saggero of Rome—said today that Pope Paul VI was under stood to have sent a personal letter to President Nixon urging him to end the United States air strikes in North Vietnam.

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: VIENNA, Dec. 27 (Reuters)— Demonstrators today daubed the entrance of a branch of the Bank of America here with red paint, protesting United States air raids on North Vietnam.

headline: On Resuming the Bombing
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Harry R. Rudin

headline: On Resuming the Bombing
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: William F. Treanor

headline: Article 3 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 27 (UPI)—Students protesting the United States bombing of North Vietnam set fire to the United States Information Serv ice office and library in Raj shahi, 100 miles northwest of Dacca, it was reported today.

headline: On Resuming the Bombing
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Stanley Hoffmann

headline: Hanoi Rejects U.S. Invitation For Technical Talks in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Dec. 27—North Viet nam refused to sit down with the United States today to dis cuss technical details of cease‐fire agreement.

headline: U.S. LISTS TARGETS OF HEAVY ATTACKS IN NORTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 28 — The United States military com mand, breaking a nine‐day si lence on damage inflicted in the intensive American air attacks against North Vietnam, listed nearly three dozen airfields, rail yards, power plants, supply depots and communications centers yesterday among the facilities that have been bombed.
author: By Joseph B. Treaster Special to The New York Times

headline: Wilson Condemns Bombing
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 27 (Reuters)—Harold Wilson, the leader of Britain's opposition Labor party, tonight condemned the American bombing of North Vietnam. Mr. Wilson is on a visit here.

headline: Visitors in Hanoi See Craters Where 10,000 Lived
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Dec. 27 (Agence France‐Presse)—In the northern Hanoi district of An Duong, between the Red River and Lake Tay, an old metal drum is jammed in some rubble beside a hole 25 feet in diameter and six feet deep.

headline: U.S. INSTALLATIONS TARGET IN PROTESTS
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27—Yugoslays angered by Unit ed States bombing of North Vietnam smeared red paint on the American Consulate in Zagreb last night and staged protest demonstrations outside the building today.

headline: On Resuming the Bombing
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: George W. Anderson

headline: Text of U.S. Communique Listing Targetg of Raids in North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 27—Following is the text of a communique issued to day by the United States mili tary command, listing targets of American air raids in North Vietnam between Dec. 18 and Dec. 25 and assessing damage:

headline: Judges Bar a Curb in U.S. Aid To Student Who Protested War
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Dec. 28 — A three‐judge Federal panel here has ruled that a law suspending Federal scholarship funds for students convicted of serious crimes is invalid because it is vague and “overbroad.”
author: By Andrew H. Malcolm Special to The New York Times

headline: Many Truman Rites Held In the Metropolitan Area
lead_paragraph: New York officials in the Federal, state and city govern ments yesterday honored Harry S. Truman at services in City Hall Plaza as, in Mayor Lind say's words, “a President who was both a leader and a lesson for all of us.”
author: By Will Lissner

headline: Key British Laborite Bids Heath Speak Up Against U.S. Bombing
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Dec. 28—The gen eral public restraint shown by top British politicians toward the American bombardment of North Vietnam ended today with a bitter attack by the most restrained of the Labor party's leaders, Roy Jenkins.
author: By Richard Eder Special to The New York Times

headline: Finnish Parties Protest
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 28 — Finland recognized North Vietnam today and eight of her nine political parties called on the United States to stop the bombing and to sign a peace treaty. Vietnam today and eight of her nine political parties called on the United States to stop the bombing and to sign a peace treaty.

headline: 16 Nations Express Concern
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 28—Yugoslavia and 15 Asian and African countries in a statement today expressed “deep concern” over the re sumption of American bombing of North Vietnam and the in terruption of the peace negotia tions in Paris.

headline: Cambodian Confession
lead_paragraph: As the aerial blitz against North Vietnam continues in full fury, the American people have been treated another sordid glimpse of what they are getting for the continuing high investment in lives, money and national honor throughout Indochina.

headline: Chou Says U.S.‐China Relations Are Imperiled by the Bombings
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Dec. 28 —Premier Chou En‐lai asked an Ameri can correspondent here tonight to let the American people know that the renewed bomb ing of North Vietnam would have an adverse effect on Chi na's relations with the United States.
author: By John Burns The Globe and Mall, Toronto

headline: No Comment by Pentagon
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28—A Defense Department spokesman had no immediate comment to day on reports of additional ci vilian casualties from the bomb ing of North Vietnam. He re ferred instead to earlier state ments at Pentagon briefings.

headline: Chou Says U.S.‐China Relations Are Imperiled by the Bombings
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Dec. 28 —Premier Chou En‐lai asked an Ameri can correspondent here tonight to let the American people know that the renewed bomb ing of North Vietnam would have an adverse effect on Chi na's relations with the United States.
author: By John Burns The Globe and Mall, Toronto

headline: Hanoi Pressing Its Charge That U.S. Snagged Talks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28— North Vietnam has undertaken an effort to convince Ameri cans and others that the Viet nam negotiations broke down in Paris not because of its re calcitrance, as charged by Washington, but because the United States made new de mands that reopened the entire scope of the negotiations.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Chou Says U.S.‐China Relations Are Imperiled by the Bombings
lead_paragraph: PEKING, Dec. 28 —Premier Chou En‐lai asked an Ameri can correspondent here tonight to let the American people know that the renewed bomb ing of North Vietnam would have an adverse effect on Chi na's relations with the United States.
author: By John Burns The Globe and Mall, Toronto

headline: Soviet Media Are Critical
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 28—The of ficial Soviet media are main taining a drumfire of criticism against the heavy air assaults on North Vietnam. The theme is broken campaign promises to American voters over the war in Indochina.

headline: South Vietnamese Training Post Near Da Nang Is Hit by Rockets
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Dec. 29 (UPI)—Enemy gun ners fired 12 122‐mm. rockets, into a South Vietnamese train ing center on the edge of Da Nang yesterday afternoon, kill ing 3 persons and wounding 13 others.

headline: ‘We Must Tell the President’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—Can we scientists meet in Washington and ignore the fact that our national Administration is launching from this city the Most massive air attacks in history? It is launching those attacks against con centrated centers of civilian popula tion, while blandly announcing lists of military targets that under these cir cumstances insult the intelligence of every thinking person. North Vietnam hardly contains military targets; and a B‐52 bombing pattern one and one‐ half miles long by one‐half mile broad, dropped, from an altitude of 30,000 feet, cannot pick out targets.
